CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: 16,17 Up to now , PCEs of the polymer solar cells incorporating BT / BO derivatives have reached 6-7 % , and hole mobilities of OFETs based on BT - containing polymers have been up to 1 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 after systematic optimization. 18,19 However , to the best of our knowledge , BT / BO - based polymers simultaneously with high field - effect mobilities and high photovoltaic performance are very rare so far. 6d,19b Thus , it still remains a big challenge to explore new BT / BO - based polymers to gain concurrently high field - effect mobility and high photovoltaic performance. On the basis of the above consideration , herein , we designed and synthesized two new D-A copolymers PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO ( Scheme 1 ) based on zNDT flanked with two thiophene units as donor unit and BT or BO as acceptor unit. We introduced two dodecyloxy substituents on BT / BO rings to guarantee good solubility of the polymers. The thermal , photophysical , and optoelectronic properties of the resulting two polymers were systematically investigated. The results showed that both the two polymers exhibit not only high fieldeffect mobilities but also high photovoltaic properties . Synthesis and Thermal Stability. The synthetic routes of monomers and corresponding polymers are outlined in Scheme 1. Monomer 1 was reacted with n-butyllithium and then with Me 3 SnCl to give compound M 1 in a good yield. Both polymers were synthesized by palladium - catalyzed Stille - coupling polymerization and purified by sequential Soxhlet extraction with methanol , hexanes , and CHCl 3 . The CHCl 3 fraction was then reduced in volume , precipitated into methanol , and collected by filtration , yielding shiny , bronze - colored solids. PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO can be readily dissolved in common solvents , such as chloroform , toluene , and chlorobenzene , and processed to form smooth and pinhole - free films upon spincoating. The molecular weights of the polymers were determined by GPC in THF solution relative to polystyrene standards , and the detailed GPC data are listed in Table 1.. Both polymers have good thermal stability with onset decomposition temperatures with 5% weight loss at 313-320 ° C . Obviously , the thermal stability of these polymers is adequate for their applications in PSCs , OFETs , and other optoelectronic devices. Optical Properties. , including the absorption peak wavelengths ( λ abs ) , the absorption edge wavelengths ( λ onset ) , and the optical band gap ( E g opt ). In Figure 3a , both of the absorption spectra recorded from dilute chloroform solutions display π-π* transitions at around 425 nm and large charge transfer features between 500 and 700 nm which are assigned by analogy to similar polymers , corresponding to intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ) between the acceptor ( BT / BO ) and donor ( NDT ) units.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph. Here are the valid entities in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PzNDTDTBT |
| PzNDTDTBO |
| BT |
| BO |
| NDT |
| M 1 |
| polystyrene |

Note that some of the entities in the paragraph are mentioned multiple times, but I have only listed each entity once in the table.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Of course! Here are the valid entities in the paragraph that refer to "Material name", presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PzNDTDTBT |
| PzNDTDTBO |

I have removed the following entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name":

* "BT" and "BO" are mentioned multiple times in the paragraph, but they are not listed as separate entities.
* "NDT" is mentioned multiple times, but it is not listed as a separate entity.
* "M 1" is not a valid entity in the paragraph.
* "polystyrene" is not mentioned as a material name in the paragraph.

Paragraph: 16,17 Up to now , PCEs of the polymer solar cells incorporating BT / BO derivatives have reached 6-7 % , and hole mobilities of OFETs based on BT - containing polymers have been up to 1 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 after systematic optimization. 18,19 However , to the best of our knowledge , BT / BO - based polymers simultaneously with high field - effect mobilities and high photovoltaic performance are very rare so far. 6d,19b Thus , it still remains a big challenge to explore new BT / BO - based polymers to gain concurrently high field - effect mobility and high photovoltaic performance. On the basis of the above consideration , herein , we designed and synthesized two new D-A copolymers PzNDTDTBT and PzNDTDTBO ( Scheme 1 ) based on zNDT flanked with two thiophene units as donor unit and BT or BO as acceptor unit. We introduced two dodecyloxy substituents on BT / BO rings to guarantee good solubility of the polymers. The thermal , photophysical , and optoelectronic properties of the resulting two polymers were systematically investigated. The results showed that both the two polymers exhibit not only high fieldeffect mobilities but also high photovoltaic properties . Synthesis and Thermal Stability. The synthetic routes of monomers and corresponding polymers are outlined in Scheme 1. Monomer 1 was reacted with n-butyllithium and then with Me 3 SnCl to give compound M 1 in a good yield. The molecular weights of the polymers were determined by GPC in THF solution relative to polystyrene standards , and the detailed GPC data are listed in Table 1.. Both polymers have good thermal stability with onset decomposition temperatures with 5% weight loss at 313-320 ° C . Obviously , the thermal stability of these polymers is adequate for their applications in PSCs , OFETs , and other optoelectronic devices. In Figure 3a , both of the absorption spectra recorded from dilute chloroform solutions display π-π* transitions at around 425 nm and large charge transfer features between 500 and 700 nm which are assigned by analogy to similar polymers , corresponding to intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ) between the acceptor ( BT / BO ) and donor ( NDT ) units.

In Figure 3a , both of the absorption spectra recorded from dilute chloroform solutions display π-π* transitions at around 425 nm and large charge transfer features between 500 and 700 nm which are assigned by analogy to similar polymers , corresponding to intramolecular charge transfer ( ICT ) between the acceptor ( BT / BO ) and donor ( NDT ) units.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the material properties mentioned in the paragraph and present them in a Markdown table.

| Property | Value |
| --- | --- |
| Polymer solar cells efficiency | 6-7% |
| Hole mobility of OFETs based on BT-containing polymers | up to 1 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 |
| Rarity of BT/BO-based polymers with high field-effect mobility and high photovoltaic performance | rare |
| Thermal stability of the polymers | adequate for applications in PSCs, OFETs, and other optoelectronic devices |
| Optical properties | λabs (absorption peak wavelength), λonset (absorption edge wavelength), E_g_opt (optical band gap) |

Now, let's break down each property and its value:

1. Polymer solar cells efficiency: The authors mention that the efficiency of polymer solar cells incorporating BT/BO derivatives has reached 6-7%.
2. Hole mobility of OFETs based on BT-containing polymers: The authors state that the hole mobility of OFETs based on BT-containing polymers has been up to 1 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 after systematic optimization.
3. Rarity of BT/BO-based polymers with high field-effect mobility and high photovoltaic performance: The authors note that BT/BO-based polymers with high field-effect mobility and high photovoltaic performance are rare.
4. Thermal stability of the polymers: The authors mention that the thermal stability of the polymers is adequate for their applications in PSCs, OFETs, and other optoelectronic devices.
5. Optical properties: The authors provide the values of the absorption peak wavelength (λabs), absorption edge wavelength (λonset), and optical band gap (E_g_opt) for the two polymers.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification.
